assumptions.title: Nonrelativistic Regime
assumptions.text: Particle velocities satisfy `v < < c` so that relativistic corrections to the kinetic energy and dynamics can be neglected. In this limit the kinetic energy is well approximated by `E ≃ p^2/(2*m)`.

assumptions.title: Classical Macroscopic Limit
assumptions.text: For macroscopic bodies with de Broglie wavelength `λ_(dB) < < L`, quantum effects such as interference and wave-particle duality are negligible and the motion can be described by classical trajectories.

symbol_definitions.definition: De Broglie wavelength of the body
Characteristic length scale of the system or apparatus

assumptions.title: Point Mass Approximation
assumptions.text: Both bodies can be treated as point masses with spherically symmetric mass distributions

assumptions.title: Inertial Reference Frame
assumptions.text: Observations are made from an inertial (non-accelerating) reference frame

assumptions.title: Conservation Laws
assumptions.text: Total energy, linear momentum and angular momentum are conserved.

symbol_definitions.definition: Total momentum vector of the system
Total angular momentum vector of the system

assumptions.title: System Isolation
assumptions.text: System is sufficiently isolated from external influences (for gravitational systems: negligible external perturbations)

assumptions.title: Perfect Blackbody
assumptions.text: The spectral energy density `u(nu,T)` describes radiation from a perfect black body - an idealized emitter that absorbs all incident radiation and re-emits it purely based on temperature `T`

assumptions.title: Thermal Equilibrium
assumptions.text: The radiation field is in thermal equilibrium at temperature `T`, meaning the emission and absorption rates are balanced and the energy distribution is time-independent

assumptions.title: Electromagnetic Polarization
assumptions.text: Electromagnetic waves have two independent polarization directions (transverse to propagation direction)

assumptions.title: Light Speed Constant
assumptions.text: The speed of light in vacuum is constant and independent of the motion of the source or observer

symbol_definitions.definition: Speed of light in vacuum, exact value by definition in SI units.

assumptions.title: Constant Relative Velocity
assumptions.text: Reference frames move with constant relative velocity (no acceleration)

assumptions.title: Variational Calculus Framework
assumptions.text: System describable by generalized coordinates `q_i(t)` with well-defined, twice-differentiable Lagrangian `L(q_i, dot q_i, t)`, smooth trajectories, and suitable boundary conditions for variational analysis (fixed endpoints, allowable interior variations)

symbol_definitions.definition: Generalized coordinates describing the system configuration
Time derivatives of generalized coordinates (generalized velocities)

assumptions.title: Stationary Action Principle
assumptions.text: The system obeys the principle of stationary action (least action principle), meaning the path taken by the system makes the action stationary, leading to the Euler-Lagrange equations

assumptions.title: Flat Spacetime
assumptions.text: Spacetime is flat, no gravitational effects considered

symbol_definitions.definition: Minkowski metric components used in special relativity, with signature `(+,-,-,-)`.
Lorentz indices running over `0,1,2,3` (Einstein summation on repeated indices).

assumptions.title: Well-Defined Rest Mass
assumptions.text: Particles have well-defined rest masses that do not depend on the reference frame

assumptions.title: Hilbert Space Probability Structure
assumptions.text: Quantum measurement outcomes correspond to orthogonal projection operators (projectors) on a complex Hilbert space `H`, where projectors are self-adjoint operators satisfying `P^2 = P = P^ast`. Probabilities can be assigned to these projectors via a probability measure `mu` mapping projectors to real numbers in `[0,1]`.

symbol_definitions.definition: Complex Hilbert space of quantum states
Projector (orthogonal projection operator) on `H`, satisfying idempotence and self-adjointness
Probability measure mapping projectors to real numbers in `[0,1]`

assumptions.title: Gleason Theorem Conditions
assumptions.text: The Hilbert space has dimension at least 3 (`dim(H) >= 3`), and the probability assignment on projectors (orthogonal projection operators `P` satisfying `P^2 = P = P^ast`) is continuous

symbol_definitions.definition: Complex Hilbert space of quantum states
Projector (orthogonal projection operator) on `H`, satisfying idempotence and self-adjointness

assumptions.title: Classical Electromagnetism Framework
assumptions.text: Fields and sources are classical, smooth (continuously differentiable, `C^1` or better), and defined on flat Minkowski spacetime. Vector calculus theorems (divergence theorem, Stokes' theorem) apply. Quantum and gravitational effects are negligible.

assumptions.title: Linear Isotropic Vacuum
assumptions.text: The medium is vacuum (free space) characterized by constants `epsilon_0` (electric permittivity) and `mu_0` (magnetic permeability), but may contain charge density `rho(r,t)` and current density `J(r,t)`. The vacuum is linear, homogeneous, and isotropic with constitutive relations `D = epsilon_0 * E` and `H = B / mu_0`.

assumptions.title: No Magnetic Monopoles
assumptions.text: Magnetic monopoles (isolated magnetic charges) have never been observed experimentally. As a consequence, the net magnetic flux through any closed surface is zero. (no free magnetic charge density exists).

assumptions.title: Coulomb's Law
assumptions.text: Electric charges interact via an inverse-square force law. A point charge `q` produces an electric field `E(r) = q / (4 * pi * epsilon_0 * r^2) * hat(r)` where `hat(r)` is the radial unit vector.
mathematical_expressions: E(r) = q / (4 * pi * epsilon_0 * r^2) * hat(r)

assumptions.title: Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction
assumptions.text: A time-varying magnetic flux through a closed circuit induces an electromotive force (emf) in that circuit. The induced emf equals the negative rate of change of magnetic flux.

assumptions.title: Ampère-Biot-Savart Law
assumptions.text: Steady electric currents generate magnetic fields that circulate around them. The line integral of magnetic field around a closed loop equals `mu_0` times the enclosed current.
mathematical_expressions: oint_C B cdot dl = mu_0 * I_(enc)

assumptions.title: Electromagnetic Field Quantization
assumptions.text: The electromagnetic field is quantized, with each mode having discrete energy levels. Each mode of frequency `nu` can only have energies that are integer multiples of `h*nu`, where `h` is Planck's constant and the integer represents the photon occupation number.

symbol_definitions.definition: Energy of mode with occupation number n

assumptions.title: Planck-de Broglie Relations
assumptions.text: Energy and momentum of matter waves are related to frequency and wavevector by `E = hbar*omega` and `p = hbar*k`.

symbol_definitions.definition: Angular frequency of the matter wave
Magnitude of wavevector of the matter wave

assumptions.title: Correspondence Principle
assumptions.text: Quantum mechanics must reproduce classical mechanics in the appropriate limit (large quantum numbers, macroscopic scales, or formally `hbar -> 0`). In particular, the quantum Hamiltonian operator is chosen so that its spectrum and dynamics reduce to those of the classical Hamiltonian `H_("classical")(p, r, t)` when quantum effects become negligible.
mathematical_expressions: H_("classical")(p, r, t) = p^2/(2*m) + V(r, t)

symbol_definitions.definition: Classical Hamiltonian function built from position, momentum and potential energy
Classical scalar potential energy as a function of position and time

assumptions.title: Quantum Superposition and Linear Dynamics
assumptions.text: Quantum states form a complex vector space and physically allowed time evolutions act linearly on this space. If `psi_1` and `psi_2` are solutions of the evolution equation, any complex linear combination `alpha*psi_1 + beta*psi_2` is also a solution.
mathematical_expressions: psi(t) = alpha*psi_1(t) + beta*psi_2(t)  =>  psi(t) " solves the same evolution equation"

symbol_definitions.definition: Complex Hilbert space of quantum states
Quantum state (e.g. wavefunction in a chosen representation)

assumptions.title: Quantum Observables as Self-Adjoint Operators
assumptions.text: Each physical observable is represented by a self-adjoint (Hermitian) operator `A` on the Hilbert space, so expectation values like `(:psi:|A|:psi:)` are real and variances defined as `Delta A^2 = (:psi:|(A - a_0)^2|:psi:)` with `a_0 = (:psi:|A|:psi:)` are non-negative.

symbol_definitions.definition: Self-adjoint operator representing a physical observable.
Normalized state vector in the quantum Hilbert space.
Expectation value of observable `A` in state `|:psi:)`, `a_0 = (:psi:|A|:psi:)`.

assumptions.title: Canonical Commutation Relations
assumptions.text: Canonical variables `q_i` and `p_i`, representing generalized coordinates and their conjugate momenta for each degree of freedom, satisfy the commutation relations `[q_i, p_j] = i*hbar*delta_(ij) `, `[q_i, q_j] = 0`, and `[p_i, p_j] = 0`. These relations encode the basic quantum kinematics of canonical pairs and fix the fundamental scale through `hbar`.

symbol_definitions.definition: Generalized coordinate operator for the `i`-th degree of freedom.

assumptions.title: Non-interacting particle approximation
assumptions.text: Particles are assumed not to interact. The total energy of a many-particle configuration is additive in the single-particle level occupations, and in the grand-canonical ensemble the partition function factorizes into independent contributions from each single-particle level.

symbol_definitions.definition: Number of particles occupying the single-particle level labeled by `r`.
Total energy of a many-particle configuration specified by occupation numbers `{n_r}`.
Energy eigenvalue of the single-particle level labeled by `r`.
Grand partition function of the full system.
Single-level contribution to the grand partition function associated with level `r`.

assumptions.title: Lorentz Covariance
assumptions.text: Spacetime symmetries act consistently on both coordinates and quantum states. For every proper orthochronous Lorentz transformation `Lambda` (a linear map of spacetime that preserves the Minkowski interval), there exists a unitary operator `U(Lambda)` on the Hilbert space such that local fields transform covariantly: the field at point `x` in one frame is related to the field at the transformed point `Lambda*x` in the new frame, with its field indices rotated by the appropriate finite-dimensional Lorentz representation `D(Lambda)` (scalar/vector/spinor, etc.).

symbol_definitions.definition: Spacetime point (4-vector), e.g. `x = (c*t, x, y, z)`.
Proper orthochronous Lorentz transformation (a real `4x4` matrix) preserving the Minkowski interval: `Lambda^T*eta*Lambda = eta`, with `det(Lambda)=1` and `Lambda_0^0 >= 1`.
Unitary operator implementing the Lorentz transformation `Lambda` on the Hilbert space of states.
Local field operator evaluated at spacetime point `x`, with component/field index `a`.
Finite-dimensional Lorentz representation acting on the field indices (e.g. `D=1` for a scalar, `D=Lambda` for a 4-vector, and `D=S(Lambda)` for a spinor).

assumptions.title: Microcausality (Locality)
assumptions.text: Microcausality is the quantum-field-theoretic formulation of relativistic causality. It states that local observables associated with spacelike-separated spacetime points correspond to mutually compatible measurements. If two spacetime points cannot be connected by signals propagating at or below the speed of light, then operations performed at one point cannot influence physical outcomes at the other. This requirement forbids superluminal signaling and ensures causal consistency of relativistic quantum theories.

symbol_definitions.definition: Local observable or field operator localized at the spacetime point `x`, constructed from quantum fields and acting nontrivially only in an arbitrarily small neighborhood of `x`.
Commutator of two operators, defined as `[A,B] = A*B - B*A`. Vanishing commutator implies that the corresponding measurements are compatible and order-independent.

Minkowski squared spacetime interval between points `x` and `y`, defined in the `(+,-,-,-)` metric convention as `(x - y)^2 = c^2*(t_x - t_y)^2 - |x_vec - y_vec|^2`. A negative value indicates spacelike separation.
Speed of light in vacuum, setting the maximum speed for causal signal propagation.

assumptions.title: Positive Energy Spectrum (Spectrum Condition)
assumptions.text: The energy-momentum spectrum is bounded below and lies in the forward light cone: physical states have `p^0 >= 0`.

assumptions.title: Existence of a Poincaré-Invariant Vacuum
assumptions.text: There exists a unique (up to phase) vacuum state `|:0:)` invariant under spacetime symmetries, from which particle states are obtained by acting with local fields.

symbol_definitions.definition: Unitary representation of a spacetime symmetry `g`.
